name: Crab Nebula
tip: Look for fuzzy oval shape; supernova remnant from 1054 AD visible in small telescopes

name: M002
tip: Bright globular in Aquarius; easily resolved in 6-inch scope under good conditions

name: M003
tip: Large, bright globular cluster; resolves well in 8-inch scope showing grainy texture

name: M004
tip: Near Antares in Scorpius; resolves easily with prominent bar of stars across center

name: M005
tip: Dense, concentrated globular; shows bright core and mottled edges in medium scopes

name: Butterfly Cluster
tip: Bright open cluster with butterfly-like shape; best viewed in binoculars or small scope

name: Ptolemy's Cluster
tip: Large, bright cluster near Scorpius stinger; naked-eye visible with scattered bright stars

name: Lagoon Nebula
tip: Large emission nebula with embedded star cluster; dark lane visible in small scopes

name: M009
tip: Compact globular near galactic center; requires 8-inch scope to begin resolution

name: M010
tip: Bright, compact globular; visible in binoculars with grainy texture in small scopes

name: Amas de l'Ecu de Sobieski
tip: Wild Duck Cluster; densely packed wedge formation resembling flying ducks in binoculars

name: M012
tip: Loose globular in Ophiuchus; resolves well in 6-inch scope with scattered outliers

name: Hercules Globular Cluster
tip: Stunning showpiece globular; resolves into thousands of stars with 6-inch scope

name: M014
tip: Small, dense globular; appears star-like in finders, needs magnification to resolve

name: M015
tip: Dense autumn globular near Enif; prominent core with 10-inch scope resolution

name: Eagle Nebula
tip: Star cluster embedded in nebulosity; Pillars of Creation visible only in large scopes

name: Checkmark Nebula
tip: Omega or Swan Nebula; horseshoe shape visible in small scopes at low power

name: M018
tip: Small sparse cluster between M17 and M24; about a dozen stars visible

name: M019
tip: Noticeably oblate globular; flattened appearance visible in moderate telescopes

name: Trifid Nebula
tip: Three-lobed emission nebula near M8; dark lanes visible in 6-inch scope

name: M021
tip: Small cluster near Trifid Nebula; bright scattered stars in binoculars

name: M022
tip: Third brightest globular in sky; resolves well showing rich star field

name: M023
tip: Large, loose open cluster; dozens of stars at low magnification

name: Small Sgr Star Cloud
tip: Not a true cluster but Milky Way star cloud; sweep with binoculars

name: M025
tip: Bright cluster with U Sagittarii variable star; wide field views excellent

name: M026
tip: Small cluster with dark nebula intrusion on south side; interesting contrast

name: Dumbbell Nebula
tip: Brightest planetary nebula; dumbbell shape obvious even in small scopes

name: M028
tip: Compact globular near M22; benefits from higher magnification to resolve

name: M029
tip: Small, sparse cluster near Sadr; appears as loose square of stars

name: M030
tip: Dense autumn globular in Capricornus; concentrated core with faint halo

name: Andromeda Galaxy
tip: Visible naked-eye as fuzzy patch; use averted vision and low power for extent

name: M032
tip: Compact elliptical companion to M31; appears as bright fuzzy star

name: Triangulum Galaxy
tip: Face-on spiral; requires dark skies and low power for best views

name: M034
tip: Large, scattered cluster in Perseus; nice binocular target with bright stars

name: M035
tip: Bright cluster near Gemini's feet; NGC 2158 visible in same field

name: M036
tip: Compact winter cluster in Auriga; bright core with scattered outliers

name: M037
tip: Richest Auriga cluster; hundreds of stars with bright orange star near center

name: M038
tip: Oblique cross or pi-shaped pattern; distinctive appearance in small scopes

name: M039
tip: Large, loose cluster in Cygnus; best in binoculars at low power

name: Winnecke 4
tip: Actually a double star, not true cluster; Messier cataloging error

name: M041
tip: Bright winter cluster south of Sirius; scattered stars fill binocular field

name: Great Orion Nebula
tip: Naked-eye in Orion's sword; Trapezium stars visible at 50x magnification

name: Mairan's Nebula
tip: Northern extension of M42; comma-shaped patch separated by dark lane

name: Beehive
tip: Praesepe naked-eye cluster; best in binoculars showing swarm of stars

name: Pleiades
tip: Seven Sisters cluster; binoculars reveal surrounding reflection nebulosity

name: M046
tip: Rich cluster with planetary nebula NGC 2438 superimposed; two objects unrelated

name: M047
tip: Bright, coarse cluster near M46; easy naked-eye under good conditions

name: M048
tip: Large, scattered cluster in Hydra; about 80 stars visible in binoculars

name: M049
tip: Brightest Virgo Cluster galaxy; large elliptical with bright core

name: M050
tip: Heart-shaped cluster in Monoceros; bright stars in loose arrangement

name: Whirlpool Galaxy
tip: Classic spiral with companion NGC 5195; spiral arms visible in 8-inch scope

name: M052
tip: Rich cluster in Cassiopeia; wedge-shaped with bright stars and faint background

name: M053
tip: Distant globular near NGC 5053; compact with bright core requiring aperture

name: M054
tip: Distant globular in Sagittarius Dwarf Galaxy; appears as fuzzy star

name: M055
tip: Large, loose globular low in Sagittarius; resolves well in moderate scopes

name: M056
tip: Small globular between Albireo and Sulafat; moderate magnification helps resolution

name: Ring Nebula
tip: Famous smoke ring between Sheliak and Sulafat; use high magnification for detail

name: M058
tip: Barred spiral in Virgo Cluster; faint requiring dark skies and aperture

name: M059
tip: Elliptical galaxy in Virgo; small and round with gradually brighter center

name: M060
tip: Bright elliptical near M59; forms trio with M58 and M59

name: M061
tip: Face-on barred spiral in Virgo; requires dark skies and large aperture

name: M062
tip: Asymmetric globular near Antares; bright core with irregular outer regions

name: Sunflower Galaxy
tip: Bright spiral with mottled appearance; spiral structure hints in large scopes

name: Black Eye Galaxy
tip: Famous dark dust lane visible in 6-inch scope near bright core

name: M065
tip: Part of Leo Triplet with M66 and NGC 3628; elongated spiral

name: M066
tip: Brightest Leo Triplet member; bright core with asymmetric dust lanes

name: M067
tip: Ancient cluster near M44; hundreds of faint stars in binoculars

name: M068
tip: Moderately bright globular in Hydra; compact core with outlying stars

name: M069
tip: Small, round globular in southern Sagittarius; requires high magnification

name: M070
tip: Faint globular near M69; compact with bright core visible in scopes

name: M071
tip: Loose globular resembling rich open cluster; between Sagitta's arrow stars

name: M072
tip: Small, faint globular near M73; requires dark skies and aperture

name: M073
tip: Not true cluster but asterism of four unrelated stars; historical curiosity

name: M074
tip: Face-on spiral in Pisces; low surface brightness requires dark skies

name: M075
tip: Compact globular southwest of M55; small but relatively bright

name: Barbell Nebula
tip: Little Dumbbell; faint planetary requiring UHC filter and large aperture

name: M077
tip: Seyfert galaxy with active nucleus; bright core visible in small scopes

name: M078
tip: Reflection nebula north of Orion's belt; two bright stars illuminate cloud

name: M079
tip: Bright southern globular in Lepus; compact with concentrated core

name: M080
tip: Dense globular midway between Antares and Graffias; very compact core

name: Bode's Galaxy
tip: Beautiful spiral visible in binoculars; pair with M82 in same field

name: Cigar Galaxy
tip: Edge-on starburst galaxy near M81; mottled appearance with dark lanes

name: Southern Pinwheel Galaxy
tip: Face-on spiral low in south; spiral arms visible in 8-inch scope

name: M084
tip: Lenticular galaxy in Virgo; elongated with bright core and jet visible large scopes

name: M085
tip: Elliptical galaxy near M84; round with gradually brighter center

name: M086
tip: Bright lenticular in Virgo Cluster; forms chain with M84 and others

name: Virgo Galaxy
tip: Giant elliptical with supermassive black hole; center of Virgo Cluster

name: M088
tip: Spiral in Virgo; elongated with faint spiral structure in large scopes

name: M089
tip: Nearly round elliptical in Virgo; smooth with gradually brighter center

name: M090
tip: Spiral galaxy in Virgo; elongated with bright core and faint extensions

name: M091
tip: Faint barred spiral in Virgo; requires dark skies and 10-inch scope

name: M092
tip: Overlooked globular near M13; densely packed with bright concentrated core

name: M093
tip: Wedge-shaped cluster in Puppis; bright stars with faint background haze

name: M094
tip: Bright spiral with prominent ring structure; compact with very bright nucleus

name: M095
tip: Barred spiral in Leo; forms trio with M96 and M105

name: M096
tip: Bright elliptical spiral in Leo group; elongated with bright stellar nucleus

name: Owl Nebula
tip: Owl eyes visible in 10-inch scope; use UHC filter for detail

name: M098
tip: Edge-on spiral in Virgo; faint with needle-like appearance requiring aperture

name: Coma Pinwheel
tip: Face-on spiral in Virgo; compact with bright core and faint spiral arms

name: M100
tip: Grand design spiral in Virgo; spiral arms visible in 8-inch scope

name: M101
tip: Pinwheel Galaxy; large and diffuse requiring dark skies and low power

name: Spindle Galaxy
tip: Edge-on lenticular in Draco; thin spindle with prominent dust lane

name: M103
tip: Arrowhead-shaped cluster in Cassiopeia; distinctive pattern of bright stars

name: Sombrero Galaxy
tip: Famous hat-shaped galaxy; dark lane visible in 6-inch scope with bright nucleus

name: M105
tip: Elliptical galaxy in Leo group; round with bright core near M95 and M96

name: M106
tip: Bright spiral near M51; mottled arms and bright core in 6-inch scope

name: M107
tip: Loose globular in Ophiuchus; scattered appearance with bright resolved stars

name: M108
tip: Edge-on spiral near M97; faint and diffuse requiring dark skies

name: M109
tip: Barred spiral below Gamma Ursae Majoris; elongated with faint bar structure

name: M110
tip: Elliptical companion to M31; appears as elongated fuzz northwest of Andromeda
